title: 112_hr3484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Travel Regional Investment Partnership Act". The importance of travel and tourism is highlighted by Congress, with millions of jobs and billions in expenditures generated by the industry. Despite some setbacks in job losses and output decline, public-private partnerships are seen as crucial for promoting domestic tourism growth. The Domestic Regional Tourism Grant Program is established under Section 3. The Secretary will establish a grant program through the Office of Travel and Tourism Industries to promote domestic regional tourism growth. Grants will range from $100,000 to $1,000,000 and can be awarded to State tourism offices, local destination marketing organizations, and partnerships between government entities and tourism organizations. Priority may be given to regions with low contributions to tourism marketing. The Secretary will establish a grant program to promote domestic regional tourism growth through partnerships with local tourism entities. Grants may prioritize regions with low contributions to tourism marketing, maintain regional diversity, and benefit rural destinations. Funds can be used to promote regional tourism growth and create new domestic tourism markets. Eligible entities must submit an application for a grant under this section. The grant program aims to promote domestic regional tourism growth and create new markets. Eligible entities must submit an application with details of tourist promotion activities to be funded. The grant program requires eligible entities to submit a description of tourist promotion activities to be funded, including details of partnerships with local tourism entities to increase regional tourism. The grant recipient must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to the grant amount, either in cash or in-kind. The partnership agreement details, how it will boost regional tourism, and the expected positive impact on job creation in the relevant domestic region must be included in the application. As a condition for receiving a grant, the recipient must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to the grant amount, with no more than 25% in in-kind contributions. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress detailing travel-generated expenditures, tax receipts, and employment within 6 months after grants are awarded. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress detailing travel-generated expenditures, tax receipts, and employment within 6 months after grants are awarded. The report should include information on local tourist entities and the authorization of appropriations for grants.
